ProcedureHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROC ESM options ; 
    BY variables ; 
    ID variable INTERVAL= interval options ; 
    FORECAST variable-list / options ; 

The ESM procedure generates forecasts by using exponential smoothing models with optimized 
smoothing weights for many time series or transactional data. 

For typical time series, you can use the following smoothing models: 
  o simple 
  o double 
  o linear 
  o damped trend 
  o seasonal 
  o Winters method (additive and multiplicative) 

Additionally, transformed versions of these models are provided: 
  o log 
  o square root 
  o logistic 
  o Box-Cox

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BACK=n] 
      
Specifies the number of observations before the end of the data where the multistep 
forecasts are to begin. The default is BACK=0.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the SAS data set that contains the input data for the procedure to forecast. 
If the DATA= option is not specified, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

[Syntax: LEAD=n] 
      
Specifies the number of periods ahead to forecast (forecast lead or horizon). 

The default is LEAD=12.

[Syntax: MAXERROR=number] 
      
Limits the number of warning and error messages produced during the execution of 
the procedure to the specified value. The default is MAXERRORS=50. This option is 
particularly useful in BY-group processing where it can be used to suppress the 
recurring messages.
Specifies that only forecasts are written to the OUT= and OUTFOR= data sets.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output data set to contain the forecasts of the variables specified 
in the subsequent FORECAST statements. If an ID variable is specified, it is 
also included in the OUT= data set. The values are accumulated based on the 
ACCUMULATE= option, and forecasts are appended to these values based on the 
FORECAST statement USE= option.

[Syntax: OUTEST=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output data set to contain the model parameter estimates and the 
associated test statistics and probability values. The OUTEST= data set is 
useful for evaluating the significance of the model parameters and understanding 
the model dynamics.

[Syntax: OUTFOR=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output data set to contain the forecast time series components (actual, 
predicted, lower confidence limit, upper confidence limit, prediction error, 
prediction standard error). The OUTFOR= data set is useful for displaying
the forecasts in tabular or graphical form.

[Syntax: OUTPROCINFO=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output data set to contain information in the SAS log, specifically 
the number of notes, errors, and warnings and the number of series processed, 
forecasts requested, and forecasts failed.

[Syntax: OUTSTAT=SAS-data-set] 
      
      
Names the output data set to contain the statistics of fit (or goodness-of-fit 
statistics). The OUTSTAT= data set is useful for evaluating how well the model 
fits the series.

[Syntax: OUTSUM=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output data set to contain the summary statistics and the forecast summation.

Specifies the graphical output desired. By default, the ESM procedure produces no 
graphical output.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Plots prediction error time series graphics.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Plots prediction error autocorrelation function graphics.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Plots prediction error partial autocorrelation function graphics.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Plots prediction error inverse autocorrelation function graphics.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Plots forecast graphics with confidence limits in the data range.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Plots the forecast in the forecast horizon only.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the printed output desired. By default, the ESM procedure produces no printed output.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Prints the results of parameter estimation.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Prints the performance statistics for each forecast.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Prints the performance summary for each BY group.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Prints the performance summary for all of the BY groups.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Prints the backcast, initial, and final states.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Prints the summary statistics for the accumulated time series.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Same as PRINT=(ESTIMATES FORECASTS STATISTICS SUMMARY)

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that output requested with the PRINT= option be printed in greater detail.

[Syntax: SEASONALITY=number] 
      
Specifies the length of the seasonal cycle. For example, SEASONALITY=3 means that 
every group of three observations forms a seasonal cycle. The SEASONALITY= option 
is applicable only for seasonal forecasting models. By default, the length of the 
seasonal cycle is one (no seasonality) or the length implied by the INTERVAL= 
option specified in the ID statement.
Specifies that the variables specified in the FORECAST statements are processed in sorted order.

[Syntax: STARTSUM=n] 
      
Specifies the starting forecast lead (or horizon) for which to begin summation of the 
forecasts specified by the LEAD= option. The STARTSUM= value must be less than the LEAD= 
value. The default is STARTSUM=1; that is, the sum from the one-step ahead forecast 
(which is the first forecast in the forecast horizon) to the multistep forecast specified 
by the LEAD= option.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ID variable INTERVAL= interval < options > ; 

The ID statement names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the input 
and output data sets. The ID variable’s values are assumed to be SAS date or datetime 
values. In addition, the ID statement specifies the (desired) frequency associated 
with the time series. The ID statement options also specify how the observations are 
accumulated and how the time ID values are aligned to form the time series to be 
forecast.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period. 
The frequency (width of each time interval) is specified by the INTERVAL= option.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip14: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Controls the alignment of SAS dates used to identify output observations.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: SAS dates aligned in the BEGINNING.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: SAS dates aligned in the MIDDLE.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: SAS dates aligned in the ENDING.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: END=date | datetime] 
          
Specifies a SAS date or datetime literal value that represents the end of the data.

[Syntax: FORMAT=format] 
          
Specifies the SAS format for the time ID values. If the FORMAT= option is not specified, 
the default format is implied from the INTERVAL= option.

Specifies the frequency of the input time series or for the time series to be accumulated 
from the input data.

Specifies that the time ID values are not in sorted order. The ESM procedure sorts 
the data with respect to the time ID prior to analysis.

Specifies how missing values (either input or accumulated) are assigned in the accumulated 
time series. If a number n is specified (SETMISSING=n), missing values are set to that 
number.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: START=date | datetime] 
          
Specifies a SAS date or datetime literal value that represents the beginning 
of the data.

Specifies how beginning and/or ending zero values (either input or accumulated) are 
interpreted in the accumulated time series.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Beginning and/or ending zeros are unchanged. This is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Beginning zeros are set to missing.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Ending zeros are set to missing.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: FORECAST variable-list / options ; 

The FORECAST statement lists the numeric variables in the DATA= data set whose 
accumulated values represent time series to be modeled and forecast. The options 
specify which forecast model is to be used.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period. The 
frequency (width of each time interval) is specified by the INTERVAL= option.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip14: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ALPHA=number] 
          
Specifies the significance level to use in computing the confidence limits of the 
forecast. The ALPHA= value must be between 0 and 1. The default is ALPHA=0.05, which 
produces 95% confidence intervals.

Specifies that the median forecast values are to be estimated. Forecasts can be based 
on the mean or median. By default, the mean value is provided. If no transformation 
is applied to the time series by using the TRANSFORM= option, the mean and median 
forecast values are identical.

Specifies the forecasting model to be used to forecast the time series. The default 
is MODEL=SIMPLE, which performs simple exponential smoothing.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Simple (single) exponential smoothing. This is the default.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: NBACKCAST=n] 
          
Specifies the number of observations used to initialize the backcast states. The 
default is the entire series.

Specifies that actual values excluded by the BACK= option are replaced with one-step-ahead 
forecasts in the OUT= data set.

Specifies that embedded missing values are replaced with one-step-ahead forecasts in 
the OUT= data set.

Specifies how missing values (either input or accumulated) are assigned in the 
accumulated time series. If a number n is specified (SETMISSING=n), missing 
values are set to that number.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the input or accumulated time series.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: No transformation. This is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Box-Cox transformation with parameter number where number is between –5 and 5.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies which forecast values are appended to the actual values in the OUT= and OUTSUM= data sets.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: The predicted values are appended to the actual values. This option is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: The lower confidence limit values are appended to the actual values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: The upper confidence limit values are appended to the actual values.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies how beginning and/or ending zero values (either input or accumulated) are interpreted in the accumulated time series.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Beginning and/or ending zeros are unchanged. This is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Beginning zeros are set to missing.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Ending zeros are set to missing.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.
